Introduction

Viral keratitis is an ocular condition characterized by inflammation of the cornea due to viral infection, most commonly herpes simplex virus.  Symptoms typically include unilateral eye pain, redness, photophobia, and watery discharge.  Examination with fluorescein stain reveals characteristic dendritic (eg, linear, branching) corneal ulcerations.  Viral keratitis is treated with antiviral medications to prevent complications, such as corneal scarring or opacification, which can lead to permanent blindness.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Viral keratitis typically results from reactivation of latent herpes simplex or varicella-zoster viruses.  Following primary infection (eg, gingivostomatitis, chickenpox), the virus is transported retrograde to sensory ganglia, where it often lies dormant for years.  Viral reactivation may be triggered by various factors including advanced age, stress, prolonged ultraviolet (UV) exposure, or immunosuppression (eg, HIV).



In the case of keratitis, reactivated virus migrates from the trigeminal ganglion via the V1 (ophthalmic) nerve to the corneal epithelium, where it begins to replicate.  An immune-mediated inflammatory response, as well as virion induced cell death, causes damage to corneal tissue.

Clinical presentation



Viral keratitis typically causes unilateral symptoms including:



  • Eye pain, foreign body sensation, photophobia (typical of any corneal process); however, some patients experience no significant pain due to decreased corneal sensation (because the V1 branch has affected sensory fibers that cause corneal anesthesia)
  • Conjunctival injection with ciliary flush (ie, erythema around the corneal border)
  • Watery discharge
  • Blurred vision/decreased visual acuity
  • A vesicular rash on the forehead, nose tip, and periorbital area is characteristically seen with varicella-zoster keratitis (ie, herpes zoster ophthalmicus (
    figure 1
    ))


Characteristic findings on slit lamp examination with fluorescein include:



  • Corneal ulcerations in a linear, branching, dendritic pattern (
    image 1
    )
  • Geographic ulcers (deeper, larger ulcerations of dendritic lesions)
  • Corneal vesicles

Diagnosis



Diagnosis is typically confirmed by slit lamp examination with fluorescein that reveals linear, branching, dendritic ulcers.  Viral culture or PCR of corneal scrapings can confirm the diagnosis in atypical cases.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of infectious keratitis includes (

):



  • Bacterial keratitis:  usually occurs from improper contact lens use or corneal trauma.  Patients typically have mucopurulent drainage, and the cornea appears hazy with a round, white ulceration (not branching lesions).
  • Fungal keratitis:  rare and typically occurs in immunocompromised patients after corneal injury involving soil/plant matter.  Onset is gradual and corneal infiltrates have characteristic feathery margins.
  • Allergic conjunctivitis:  typically presents with bilateral (rather than unilateral) itching, tearing, and redness; patients also usually have other allergic symptoms (eg, rhinitis).
  • Dry eye syndrome:  insufficient tear production or poor tear quality, which causes ocular surface inflammation.  Symptoms of dryness, burning, foreign body sensation, and fluctuating vision are exacerbated by environmental triggers (eg, wind, air conditioning).

Management



Management of viral keratitis requires prompt initiation of antiviral agents.  Both topical and oral antiviral medications are considered effective therapies, although oral antiviral treatment is typically preferred in varicella-zoster keratitis (due to involvement of facial structures).  Treatment decisions should be made in consultation with an ophthalmologist, and patients need close outpatient monitoring.

Prognosis



Prognosis varies depending on the severity of the infection and the timing of diagnosis and treatment.  With prompt intervention, many cases resolve without significant sequelae; however, untreated infection is a major cause of blindness worldwide.  Recurrent episodes, particularly with herpes simplex virus, further increase the risk of complications such as corneal scarring, which may lead to permanent visual impairment.

Summary



Viral keratitis is a potentially vision-threatening condition that involves inflammation of the cornea.  Herpes simplex virus is the most common etiology.  Patients typically have eye pain, redness, photophobia, clear discharge, or foreign body sensation.  The characteristic finding on fluorescein examination is dendritic ulcerations on the corneal epithelium.  Treatment is topical or oral antiviral medications.
